title: AFP Pension Privatization Reform
summary: Chile's 1981 pension privatization, designed by José Piñera under the Pinochet dictatorship, replaced the public pay-as-you-go system with individual capitalization accounts managed by private AFPs. Despite strong investment returns, replacement rates averaged only 33–40%, generating mass protests and ongoing reform debates.
content:
## Background

Prior to 1981, Chile operated a fragmented public pension system with over 150 separate schemes covering different occupational groups. The system was financially unsustainable, with generous benefits for some groups (notably the military and civil servants), inadequate coverage for others, and a worker-to-retiree ratio that was declining. Pension expenditures consumed a large share of the national budget, and benefits varied enormously depending on political influence.

The Pinochet military government (1973–1990), advised by the "Chicago Boys" — Chilean economists trained at the University of Chicago — undertook sweeping market-oriented reforms. Labor Minister José Piñera designed the pension privatization as a cornerstone of this transformation, arguing that individual accounts would eliminate political manipulation, improve capital market development, and provide better returns than a pay-as-you-go system.

## The Intervention

Decree Law 3,500 of November 1980 (effective May 1981) replaced the public pension system with a mandatory individual capitalization model. All new labor market entrants were required to join the private system, while existing workers could choose to switch (with incentives to do so — including a "recognition bond" for prior contributions). The military and police were exempt and retained their generous public pensions.

Workers contribute 10% of wages to individual accounts managed by Administradoras de Fondos de Pensiones (AFPs) — private, for-profit pension fund management companies. Workers choose among competing AFPs, which invest funds in diversified portfolios of equities, bonds, and other instruments. An additional ~1.5% covers disability and survivor insurance plus AFP administrative fees. At retirement, workers use accumulated savings to purchase an annuity or take programmed withdrawals.

The system was initially lauded internationally. Annual real investment returns averaged 8–10% during the first two decades, well above projections. Chile's capital markets deepened significantly, with AFP assets growing to over 70% of GDP. The World Bank promoted the Chilean model in its influential 1994 report "Averting the Old Age Crisis," and over 30 countries adopted variations of the individual capitalization approach.

## Results & Evidence

The Bravo Commission (Comisión Asesora Presidencial sobre el Sistema de Pensiones), appointed by President Bachelet in 2014 and reporting in 2015, produced the most comprehensive assessment. Its findings were sobering: the median replacement rate — the pension as a share of the worker's last salary — was only 34% for men and even lower for women. Approximately 50% of retirees received pensions below the minimum wage.

Borzutzky (2002) in *Vital Connections: Politics, Social Security, and Inequality in Chile* documented how the privatized system systematically disadvantaged workers with interrupted employment histories — particularly women (who leave the workforce for caregiving), informal sector workers, and the self-employed. Women's pensions averaged approximately 60% of men's, reflecting lower wages, more career interruptions, and earlier retirement age (60 vs. 65).

Barr and Diamond (2008) argued that Chile's experience demonstrated fundamental problems with the individual account model: high administrative costs (AFPs charged fees that consumed 15–20% of contributions over a working lifetime), inadequate coverage of informal workers, and the transfer of all investment and longevity risk to individuals.

The 2008 reform under President Bachelet's first administration added a Pilar Solidario (Solidarity Pillar), providing a basic non-contributory pension (Pensión Básica Solidaria) to the poorest 60% of the elderly and a top-up (Aporte Previsional Solidario) for those with low contributory pensions. This partially addressed the coverage gap but did not change the fundamental AFP structure.

## Challenges & Criticisms

Mass protests erupted in 2016 under the "No más AFP" movement, with hundreds of thousands marching nationwide demanding fundamental reform. Public opinion polls consistently showed over 70% disapproval of the AFP system. The protests reflected not only inadequate pension levels but broader frustration with a model perceived as enriching financial firms at workers' expense — AFP companies consistently generated high profits.

During the COVID-19 crisis (2020–2021), the Chilean Congress authorized three rounds of emergency pension fund withdrawals, totaling approximately $50 billion — roughly 30% of total AFP assets. While providing immediate relief to households, the withdrawals severely depleted retirement savings, particularly for younger workers, and will further reduce future pension adequacy.

The 2022 constitutional convention proposed replacing the AFP system entirely, but the draft constitution was rejected in a September 2022 referendum. Pension reform remained a central political issue, with the Boric government proposing a mixed system incorporating both individual accounts and a collective solidarity component.

## Key Lessons

- Individual capitalization systems can generate strong financial returns but may deliver inadequate pension replacement rates, particularly for workers with interrupted careers
- Pension privatization transfers risk from the state to individuals, who may be poorly positioned to manage investment and longevity risks
- Administrative costs in competitive private systems can consume a significant share of retirement savings over a working lifetime
- Gender-blind pension designs produce gender-inequitable outcomes when labor markets are gendered
- Pension systems require solidarity mechanisms to provide adequate coverage for those outside formal employment; purely contributory models exclude large segments of the population

## References

1. Comisión Asesora Presidencial sobre el Sistema de Pensiones (Bravo Commission). (2015). *Informe Final*. Santiago: Government of Chile.
2. Borzutzky, S. (2002). *Vital Connections: Politics, Social Security, and Inequality in Chile*. Notre Dame: University of Notre Dame Press.
3. Barr, N., & Diamond, P. (2008). *Reforming Pensions: Principles and Policy Choices*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
4. Mesa-Lago, C. (2008). *Reassembling Social Security: A Survey of Pensions and Health Care Reforms in Latin America*. Oxford: Oxford University Press.
